para.sentence: Other formulas of this kind can be constructed by inversion of the differentiation formulas given in §13.3(ii).

\int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-zt}t^{b-1}{\mathbf{M}}\left(a,c,kt\right)\mathrm{d}t= \Gamma\left(b\right)z^{-b}{{}_{2}{\mathbf{F}}_{1}}\left(a,b;c;\ifrac{k}{z} \right), if \Re b>0, \Re z>\max\left(\Re k,0\right), \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-zt}t^{b-1}{\mathbf{M}}\left(a,b,t\right)\mathrm{d}t=z^{-b }\left(1-\frac{1}{z}\right)^{-a}, if \Re b>0, \Re z>1, \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-t}t^{b-1}{\mathbf{M}}\left(a,c,t\right)\mathrm{d}t=\frac{ \Gamma\left(b\right)\Gamma\left(c-a-b\right)}{\Gamma\left(c-a\right)\Gamma \left(c-b\right)}, if \Re(c-a)>\Re b>0, \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-zt-t^{2}}t^{2b-2}{\mathbf{M}}\left(a,b,t^{2}\right) \mathrm{d}t=\tfrac{1}{2}\pi^{-\frac{1}{2}}\Gamma\left(b-\tfrac{1}{2}\right)U \left(b-\tfrac{1}{2},a+\tfrac{1}{2},\tfrac{1}{4}z^{2}\right), if \Re b>\tfrac{1}{2}, \Re z>0, \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-zt}t^{b-1}U\left(a,c,t\right)\mathrm{d}t=\Gamma\left(b \right)\Gamma\left(b-c+1\right)\*z^{-b}{{}_{2}{\mathbf{F}}_{1}}\left(a,b;a+b-c +1;1-\frac{1}{z}\right), if \Re b>\max\left(\Re c-1,0\right), \Re z>0.
For additional Laplace transforms seeErdélyi et al. (1954a, §§4.22,5.20),Oberhettinger and Badii (1973, §1.17), andPrudnikov et al. (1992a, §§3.34, 3.35).
Inverse Laplace transforms are given inOberhettinger and Badii (1973, §2.16) andPrudnikov et al. (1992b, §§3.33, 3.34).
For additional Mellin transforms see Erdélyi et al. (1954a, §§6.9, 7.5),Marichev (1983, pp. 283–287), and Oberhettinger (1974, §§1.13, 2.8).
For additional Fourier transforms see Erdélyi et al. (1954a, §§1.14, 2.14, 3.3) and Oberhettinger (1990, §§1.22,2.22).
For additional Hankel transforms and also other Bessel transforms see Erdélyi et al. (1954b, §8.18) andOberhettinger (1972, §§1.16 and 3.4.42–46,4.4.45–47,5.94–97).
For integral transforms in terms of Whittaker functions see §13.23(iv).

Additional integrals can be found inApelblat (1983, pp. 388–392), Erdélyi et al. (1954b),Gradshteyn and Ryzhik (2000, §7.6), Magnus et al. (1966, §6.1.2),Prudnikovet al. (1990, §§1.13, 1.14, 2.19, 4.2.2),Prudnikovet al. (1992a, §§3.35, 3.36), andPrudnikov et al. (1992b, §§3.33, 3.34).See also (13.4.2), (13.4.5), (13.4.6).
Generalized orthogonality integrals (33.14.13) and (33.14.15) can be expressed in terms of Kummer functions via the definitions in that section.
